awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Accelerating the pace of research and implementation of Writing-to-Learn pedagogies across STEM disciplines
awd_abstract_narration:
National reports point to the importance of fostering a globally competitive science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) knowledgeable workforce and a STEM literate population.  This research represents a significant advance in understanding how Writing To Learn (WTL) pedagogies promote learning in science through mediating and moderating factors (i.e., mechanisms of effect).  Focused on introductory and capstone courses, the research has the potential to be relevant across course levels, STEM disciplines, department, and institutions.  Additionally, the research will advance knowledge of how faculty think about and use WTL in STEM, how WTL pedagogies can most effectively be developed with faculty (avoiding the failures of entirely pre-packaged curricula), and how to build and stimulate a nation-wide faculty network.  The use of a common heuristic framework, protocols, and metrics and a shared implementation technology platform provides an opportunity to investigate WTL pedagogies in STEM and associated student achievement outcomes at an unprecedented scale.

Phase 4 of this research and implementation program investigates and promotes WLT pedagogies.  Through integrating and expanding ongoing research across institutions, the overarching goals are to broaden the scope of systematic investigation of WTL practices in STEM education and to accelerate the pace of widespread adoption of WTL in STEM courses.  A set of quasi-experimental studies of WTL in introductory and capstone courses in biology, chemistry, physics and statistics will examine student outcomes and moderating and mediating variables in the context of STEM courses.  The combination of cross-sectional and longitudinal studies of student cognitive and affective outcomes with large sample sizes will contribute to establishing both construct and predictive validity of mediating/moderating variables and processes associated with student learning outcomes across a broad range of students, institutions, and conditions.

por.por_cntn:
This project worked to broaden the scope of systematic research of Writing-to-Learn (WTL) practices in STEM education and to accelerate the pace of wide-spread adoption of WTL in STEM courses.  To achieve these goals, we integrated and expanded ongoing research initiatives at the three partner institutions: Duke University?s conceptual framework and focus on mechanisms of effect, University of Michigan?s use of automated peer review as an accelerator for evidence-based WTL in STEM courses, and UMN?s Writing-Enriched Curriculum model for faculty development and dissemination of WTL pedagogies. 

Our first major research question was: How do STEM faculty use WTL pedagogies to promote learning and disciplinary epistemic beliefs?  To address this question, we sent a survey to ~28,000 STEM faculty at universities across the United States. By analyzing the ~5,000 responses, we now have a better understanding of: 1) what motivates and inhibits faculty from assigning writing in their courses; 2) faculty conceptions of writing in the classroom, and 3) how faculty?s beliefs about knowledge (i.e., their epistemic beliefs) influence their decisions to assign writing in their courses.

 Our second major research question was: How do WTL pedagogies promote deep conceptual learning and critical thinking?  In other words, could we identify the variables that meditate and moderate the relationship between the processes of writing and learning?  To address this question, we developed writing assignments for large, introductory courses in biology, chemistry, ecology, and statistics departments at the three collaborating universities, and implemented a student survey to measure student characteristics that may explain how writing influences learning. We then developed and tested a conceptual model of mediation and moderation (Figure 1) where yellow boxes represent relatively stable inputs, the green box represents educational interventions, and red boxes represent outcomes. 

See Figure 1: Conceptual model of mediation and moderation (attached)

Educational context includes the university, discipline, instructor, etc. in which the intervention occurs. Student characteristics describe who students are before they begin the intervention, and include fixed characteristics such as demographics (gender, race/ethnicity, class rank, native language, and identification with a group about which there is a negative stereotype), as well as malleable characteristics such as major and pre-course intrapersonal attributes (epistemic beliefs, self-efficacy in science practice, self-efficacy in writing, science identity, and motivation). The impact of an Intervention (e.g., a writing assignment) on the outcome Conceptual learning may be direct (path a, controlling for path f) and/or indirect, mediated by Changes in intrapersonal attributes (path b-c), and/or moderated by Student characteristics(path d). The impact of an Intervention (i.e., a writing-intensive course) on the outcome Changes in intrapersonal attributes (defined as post-course minus pre-course scores for each intrapersonal attribute) may be direct (path b, controlling for path g) and/or moderated by Student characteristics (path e).  

Our third major question was:  Is it possible to develop an effective, nation-wide "WTL in STEM" Faculty Network?   We successfully implemented two STEMWrite Summer Institutes with teams of faculty and writing specialists from Auburn University, University of California, Santa Barbara, University of Kansas, University of Kentucky, University of Massachusetts-Lowell, University of California-San Diego, Syracuse University, and Stony Brook University.  At the institutes, teams developed writing assignments and implementation strategies for targeted courses at their home institutions. Post-institutes, we hosted monthly video meetings and a STEMwrite listserv to help Institute alumni sustain engagement, trouble-shoot, and refine implementation strategies.  The third STEMWrite Summer Institute will take place in 2022 as part of a supplemental grant.
